clinicalDescription: Overview: A chronic condition in which the pancreas produces little or no insulin to control blood sugar levels. Type 1 diabetes was previously called insulin-dependent diabetes or juvenile diabetes. It typically appears in adolescence. Type 1 is the most common form of diabetes under age 30, but it can occur at any age.Presentation: thirst, frequent urination, hunger, fatigue, and blurred vision, bed-wetting in kids who previously did not wet the bed Assessment: Glycated hemoglobin (A1C) test, random or fasting blood sugar tests, urinalysis, and blood tests for autoantibodies Plan: blood sugar monitoring, insulin therapy, diet, and exercise - diabetes management Prognosis: Careful management reduces the risk of serious — even life-threatening — complications.
